edu.columbia.cs.sdarts.common
Class LSPFilter

java.lang.Object
  |
  +--edu.columbia.cs.sdarts.common.LSPObject
        |
        +--edu.columbia.cs.sdarts.common.LSPFilter
All Implemented Interfaces:
java.lang.Cloneable
public class LSPFilter
extends LSPObject
implements java.lang.Cloneable

Represents a "filter", as defined in STARTS 1.0. A filter is used to specify the actual filtering terms of the search.

Sometimes, a back-end developer need never instantiate an LSPFilter, but simply read one that has been passed from the front end inside an LSPQuery. The LSPResults object that the back end returns must include the actual filter used.

In the case where the wrapped collection does not fully support the requested filter, the back end developer must instantiate a new filter that represents the supported subset of the requested filter, and include it in the LSPResults object. See QueryProcessor and StandardQueryProcessor for help in doing this. An LSPFilter can be altered using the various set() methods described below. In addition, an LSPFilter is Cloneable; in this way, a parent LSPQuery can be cloned, and the filter in the clone can be manipulated directly using the set() methods. An LSPFilter makes only a shallow clone.

A filter can be of three types:

  • TERM: a single LSPTerm
  • TERM_PROXOP_TERM: an LSPTerm, followed by an LSPProxOp, followed by an LSPTerm.
  • FILTER_BOOLEANOP_FILTER: an LSPFilter, followed by an LSPBooleanOp, followed by an LSPFilter.
Accessors for the type, and for all possible elements within the filter, are included in this class.

public int getType()
Return the type of filter this is: either TERM, TERM_PROXOP_TERM, or FILTER_BOOLEANOP_FILTER.

getTerm

public LSPTerm getTerm()
Return the LSPTerm associated with this filter, if type is TERM. If type is TERM_PROXOP_TERM, will return the first LSPTerm. Else, returns null.
Returns:
the LSPTerm associated with this filter, if type is TERM. If type is TERM_PROXOP_TERM, will return the first LSPTerm. Else, returns null.
